Expectation1: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation1: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: The bell above the salon door jingled, and I glanced up from my station. A woman hovered at the entrance, clutching her purse, eyes darting nervously. I knew that look—first-time jitters. As a hairdresser, it was my job to greet her warmly, to make her feel at ease, to show her she was in good hands. I started toward her, rehearsing my most reassuring smile. But then I glanced at the clock. My volunteer shift at the community kitchen started in fifteen minutes. I was supposed to be there on time, to set an example, to show commitment. Still, I knew the others could handle things if I was a little late. My heart thudded as I hesitated, torn between the anxious client who needed comfort and the promise I’d made to the kitchen. Both roles tugged at me, each with its own expectations, and I stood frozen, caught between the welcoming words on my lips and the ticking clock in my mind.
